GOD.content: possibility of literature announced, folded, in repli of fathomless secret [Gospel fold of Abrahamic], more Abrahamic than Greek, à se donner la mort à mort
GOD.linkedContent: possibility of literature announced, folded, in repli of fathomless secret [Gospel fold of Abrahamic], more Abrahamic than Greek, à se donner la mort à mort

GOD.content: every text consigned to public space can become a literary object [Schreber]
GOD.linkedContent: every text consigned to public space can become a literary object [Schreber]

GOD.content: reader of literature hypnotized, paralyzed before suspended perplexity, before secret path of secret, exposed and concealed, jealously sealed: who says what to whom? who asks forgiveness?
GOD.linkedContent: reader of literature hypnotized, paralyzed before suspended perplexity, before secret path of secret, exposed and concealed, jealously sealed: who says what to whom? who asks forgiveness?

GOD.content: future of a perhaps in literature, a secret that perhaps might not be one
GOD.linkedContent: future of a perhaps in literature, a secret that perhaps might not be one

GOD.content: “pardon for not meaning (to say),” secretless secret of literature, scene of forgiveness, its being “up in the air” keeps it secret, announces literature
GOD.linkedContent: “pardon for not meaning (to say),” secretless secret of literature, scene of forgiveness, its being “up in the air” keeps it secret, announces literature

GOD.content: forgiveness as im-possible, experience of this impossibility is received differently
GOD.linkedContent: forgiveness as im-possible, experience of this impossibility is received differently

GOD.content: the phrase [“pardon for…”] is “up in the air”: an appearance that comes from who knows where, contingency (touch, tact, contact), & pertinent (touching, tact, contact) > dwells suspended in air, even when it touches, meteoric, suspended like Abraham’s knife over Isaac’s head
GOD.linkedContent: the phrase [“pardon for…”] is “up in the air”: an appearance that comes from who knows where, contingency (touch, tact, contact), & pertinent (touching, tact, contact) > dwells suspended in air, even when it touches, meteoric, suspended like Abraham’s knife over Isaac’s head

GOD.content: filiation of impossible filiations: Kafka & Abraham, their spectral fathers, in scene of forgiveness, literature & secrecy
GOD.linkedContent: filiation of impossible filiations: Kafka & Abraham, their spectral fathers, in scene of forgiveness, literature & secrecy

GOD.content: father accuses literary writing of parasitism, the son should have worked instead of written [pharmakon, meteor]
GOD.linkedContent: father accuses literary writing of parasitism, the son should have worked instead of written [pharmakon, meteor]

GOD.content: fabled reader (deciphers) vs. infinite reader (sees in the secret the avowal of literature)
GOD.linkedContent: fabled reader (deciphers) vs. infinite reader (sees in the secret the avowal of literature)

GOD.content: secret letter becomes literature [Kafka] when it risks publicity, destinerrance, an archive to be inherited, when abandoned to its undecidability (is it the signature of father or son?)
GOD.linkedContent: secret letter becomes literature [Kafka] when it risks publicity, destinerrance, an archive to be inherited, when abandoned to its undecidability (is it the signature of father or son?)

GOD.content: w/ no witness, can only come down to us in the trace of an inheritance
GOD.linkedContent: w/ no witness, can only come down to us in the trace of an inheritance

GOD.content: after the flood, God reminds himself of the promise of the covenant, in the meteoric [trace] of a rainbow, that is, not merely in spontaneous, living, autoaffective memory [Derrida here showing literature’s relation to Jewish God]
GOD.linkedContent: after the flood, God reminds himself of the promise of the covenant, in the meteoric [trace] of a rainbow, that is, not merely in spontaneous, living, autoaffective memory [Derrida here showing literature’s relation to Jewish God]

GOD.content: literature desacralizes the world like Abraham’s sacrifice [in the name of a secret w/out content]
GOD.linkedContent: literature desacralizes the world like Abraham’s sacrifice [in the name of a secret w/out content]

GOD.content: literature, w/ its right to say & hide everything, inseparable from a democracy to come
GOD.linkedContent: literature, w/ its right to say & hide everything, inseparable from a democracy to come

GOD.content: singularity is sealed & betrayed by inheritance that confirms, reads, translates the covenant; literature inherits from Abraham, betrays him > secularization of holy revelation?
GOD.linkedContent: singularity is sealed & betrayed by inheritance that confirms, reads, translates the covenant; literature inherits from Abraham, betrays him > secularization of holy revelation?

GOD.content: literature as inheritance of promise of betrayal, w/ the forswearing [Kafka’s Letter to Father] that haunts this oath?
GOD.linkedContent: literature as inheritance of promise of betrayal, w/ the forswearing [Kafka’s Letter to Father] that haunts this oath?

GOD.content: literature, place of secrets w/out secrecy, all these crypts w/out depth, no other basis than abyss of call or address; only law: singularity of event called the work (l’oeuvre)
GOD.linkedContent: literature, place of secrets w/out secrecy, all these crypts w/out depth, no other basis than abyss of call or address; only law: singularity of event called the work (l’oeuvre)

GOD.content: properly phenomenological virtue of literature: puts thesis or arrest in quotations (parentheses) > literature’s relation to non-literary, religious remainder (Abrahamic moment), betrays in double sense of word: unfaithful to its history at moment it uncovers that history’s secret, reveals its “truth” (i.e. its [literature’s] own filiation) > literature must ask forgiveness for this double betrayal
GOD.linkedContent: properly phenomenological virtue of literature: puts thesis or arrest in quotations (parentheses) > literature’s relation to non-literary, religious remainder (Abrahamic moment), betrays in double sense of word: unfaithful to its history at moment it uncovers that history’s secret, reveals its “truth” (i.e. its [literature’s] own filiation) > literature must ask forgiveness for this double betrayal

GOD.content: asks forgiveness as from the very first word
GOD.linkedContent: asks forgiveness as from the very first word

GT.content: reader is not deceived [like narrator], experiences a secret w/out depth, a secret w/out secret
GT.linkedContent: reader is not deceived [like narrator], experiences a secret w/out depth, a secret w/out secret

GT.content: Baudelaire’s “Counterfeit Money,” its play w/ title, links literature to belief, credit, thus capital, economy, politics
GT.linkedContent: Baudelaire’s “Counterfeit Money,” its play w/ title, links literature to belief, credit, thus capital, economy, politics

GT.content: a “true” corpus is still, perhaps, counterfeit money, may be ghost or spirit, spirit of body & of capital (title, heading, is capital), no problem of canon if this institution were natural
GT.linkedContent: a “true” corpus is still, perhaps, counterfeit money, may be ghost or spirit, spirit of body & of capital (title, heading, is capital), no problem of canon if this institution were natural

GT.content: writing subject does not have to be giving subject; subject as such: bordered, posed, identified, always calculates, reappropriates surplus-value, circular return, a certain capitalization
GT.linkedContent: writing subject does not have to be giving subject; subject as such: bordered, posed, identified, always calculates, reappropriates surplus-value, circular return, a certain capitalization

GT.content: despite labor of subject, production of surplus-value, gift takes place where there’s trace, dissemination, in excessive forgetting, forgetful excess of the gift
GT.linkedContent: despite labor of subject, production of surplus-value, gift takes place where there’s trace, dissemination, in excessive forgetting, forgetful excess of the gift

GT.content: whole economy of narrative [“Counterfeit Money”] proceeds from a remainder, change returned, return of an unproductive expenditure [capitalizes?]
GT.linkedContent: whole economy of narrative [“Counterfeit Money”] proceeds from a remainder, change returned, return of an unproductive expenditure [capitalizes?]

GT.content: literature & its relation to capital, city, polis, transformation of monetary forms [late capitalism] (dematerializaiton of money & all the scenes that depend on it)
GT.linkedContent: literature & its relation to capital, city, polis, transformation of monetary forms [late capitalism] (dematerializaiton of money & all the scenes that depend on it)

GT.content: [re: “Counterfeit Money”] only a liar could know whether friend gave real money, that is, a connoisseur of counterfeit money; so narrator believes, credits his friend
GT.linkedContent: [re: “Counterfeit Money”] only a liar could know whether friend gave real money, that is, a connoisseur of counterfeit money; so narrator believes, credits his friend

GT.content: literature as place of non-place of frame, triptych w/ dislocated frame, 3 + or – excluded 4th, all positions exchangeable to infinity, an ex-propriation that forbids a return to self, most powerful or interesting speculation
GT.linkedContent: literature as place of non-place of frame, triptych w/ dislocated frame, 3 + or – excluded 4th, all positions exchangeable to infinity, an ex-propriation that forbids a return to self, most powerful or interesting speculation

GT.content: readers are at once debtors & creditors, like the narrator, we are the beggar, the 3rd party excluded from the secret of the dual scene
GT.linkedContent: readers are at once debtors & creditors, like the narrator, we are the beggar, the 3rd party excluded from the secret of the dual scene

GT.content: readability of text structured by unreadability of secret, narrator in situation analogous to reader; crypt gives to be read, eternally unreadable
GT.linkedContent: readability of text structured by unreadability of secret, narrator in situation analogous to reader; crypt gives to be read, eternally unreadable

GT.content: [no depth beyond literary phenomenon] inviolability of secret depends on essential superficiality, bare device of being-two-to-speak (l’être-deux-à-parler), a secret beyond reserve of technique, thing, being, thing thought (same could be said for money)
GT.linkedContent: [no depth beyond literary phenomenon] inviolability of secret depends on essential superficiality, bare device of being-two-to-speak (l’être-deux-à-parler), a secret beyond reserve of technique, thing, being, thing thought (same could be said for money)

GT.content: Baudelaire inscribes a naturalization in institution called literature, narrator occupies place of nature; via simulacrum, narrative resembles birth of literature
GT.linkedContent: Baudelaire inscribes a naturalization in institution called literature, narrator occupies place of nature; via simulacrum, narrative resembles birth of literature

GT.content: secret of literature has no depth, no interiority, spread on the surface of the page, non-psychological structure, not subjective though responsible for most radical effects of subjectivity, a post card, a bank note, a “letter of credit”  [see LOBL p. ~101, & SUBJECTILE]
GT.linkedContent: secret of literature has no depth, no interiority, spread on the surface of the page, non-psychological structure, not subjective though responsible for most radical effects of subjectivity, a post card, a bank note, a “letter of credit” [see LOBL p. ~101, & SUBJECTILE]

MONL.content: most authoritarian cultural clichés = indefatigable generation of the literary superego
MONL.linkedContent: most authoritarian cultural clichés = indefatigable generation of the literary superego

R.content: democracy opens public space by granting change of tone (Weschsel der Töne), irony as well as fiction, simulacrum, secret, literature
R.linkedContent: democracy opens public space by granting change of tone (Weschsel der Töne), irony as well as fiction, simulacrum, secret, literature

FL.content: justice is all fields: literary, ethical, etc.
FL.linkedContent: justice is all fields: literary, ethical, etc.

MC.content: “psychoanalysis,” “literature”—proper names that point to historical, singular events or series of events; p. 345 it is not certain such “worlds” exist
MC.linkedContent: “psychoanalysis,” “literature”—proper names that point to historical, singular events or series of events; p. 345 it is not certain such “worlds” exist

MC.content: privilege of literature: its proper name is a place of chance
MC.linkedContent: privilege of literature: its proper name is a place of chance

MC.content: not that all fiction, all inscription of proper names has literary dimension, but they arise in a place where limits are never real, never immobile, never solid—only the effects of contextual isolation > pragrammatological (intersection of pragmatics & grammatology)
MC.linkedContent: not that all fiction, all inscription of proper names has literary dimension, but they arise in a place where limits are never real, never immobile, never solid—only the effects of contextual isolation > pragrammatological (intersection of pragmatics & grammatology)

MC.content: [artist as pervert?] art (particularly literature) can isolate performatively its own context for its own event > the “oeuvre”
MC.linkedContent: [artist as pervert?] art (particularly literature) can isolate performatively its own context for its own event > the “oeuvre”

MC.content: this large, stereotomic margin of play is perhaps largest of all (during certain history) but not infinite [?] [see also Christianity/Capitalism not infinite]
MC.linkedContent: this large, stereotomic margin of play is perhaps largest of all (during certain history) but not infinite [?] [see also Christianity/Capitalism not infinite]

H.content: through philosophy and literature we interrogate our language

AF.content: juridical fiction produces continuity of fiction
AF.linkedContent: juridical fiction produces continuity of fiction

POO.content: Derrida does not like literature for its own sake, for some pleasure, or aesthetic, but for the secret, the passion of the secret, the secret of the passion > in place of the secret only remainder remains, not even literature.
POO.linkedContent: Derrida does not like literature for its own sake, for some pleasure, or aesthetic, but for the secret, the passion of the secret, the secret of the passion > in place of the secret only remainder remains, not even literature.

POO.content: literature: right to say everything, w/out ever touching the secret
POO.linkedContent: literature: right to say everything, w/out ever touching the secret

POO.content: each time literary work is censured, democracy is in danger
POO.linkedContent: each time literary work is censured, democracy is in danger

POO.content: literature’s authorization to say everything acknowledges right to absolute nonresponse
POO.linkedContent: literature’s authorization to say everything acknowledges right to absolute nonresponse

POO.content: this nonresponse is hyperbolic condition of democracy (democracy to-come) contradicts historically limited democracy where calculable subject has to tell truth, has to reveal secret before the law (doctors, confession, psychoanalyst, lawyer, national defense)
POO.linkedContent: this nonresponse is hyperbolic condition of democracy (democracy to-come) contradicts historically limited democracy where calculable subject has to tell truth, has to reveal secret before the law (doctors, confession, psychoanalyst, lawyer, national defense)

POO.content: literary is only exemplary of what happens everywhere
POO.linkedContent: literary is only exemplary of what happens everywhere

POO.content: identifiable institutions stabilize, arrest turbulence, master, order, to be able to make decisions, to be able > literature is exemplary in the face of this, it always does something other, something other than itself: for example: philosophy (literature & philosophy)
POO.linkedContent: identifiable institutions stabilize, arrest turbulence, master, order, to be able to make decisions, to be able > literature is exemplary in the face of this, it always does something other, something other than itself: for example: philosophy (literature & philosophy)

POO.content: literature’s exemplarity: secret in tact, modesty more jealous than ever
POO.linkedContent: literature’s exemplarity: secret in tact, modesty more jealous than ever

BL.content: juridical fiction: “legal personality of the text”
BL.linkedContent: juridical fiction: “legal personality of the text”

BL.content: instability of of the judicial events, the positive law, re: literature, re: several or singular authors > these problems arise in every historical modulation
BL.linkedContent: instability of of the judicial events, the positive law, re: literature, re: several or singular authors > these problems arise in every historical modulation

BL.content: no such thing as literary essence, name literature destined to remain improper: has something to do w/ drama of name, law of name, name of law
BL.linkedContent: no such thing as literary essence, name literature destined to remain improper: has something to do w/ drama of name, law of name, name of law

BL.content: does law share the conditions of its possibility w/ the literary object?
BL.linkedContent: does law share the conditions of its possibility w/ the literary object?

BL.content: origin of literature at same time as origin of law; story of prohibition (law) is a prohibited story
BL.linkedContent: origin of literature at same time as origin of law; story of prohibition (law) is a prohibited story

BL.content: knowing neither who nor what is the law: literature begins
BL.linkedContent: knowing neither who nor what is the law: literature begins

BL.content: semantic contents of philosophy could never explain the “literary” of this story w/out story [re: Kafka’s “Before the Law”]
BL.linkedContent: semantic contents of philosophy could never explain the “literary” of this story w/out story [re: Kafka’s “Before the Law”]

BL.content: what differs in each literature is framing and reference
BL.linkedContent: what differs in each literature is framing and reference

BL.content: literature: perturbs referentiality while revealing essential structure of referentiality
BL.linkedContent: literature: perturbs referentiality while revealing essential structure of referentiality

BL.content: literature: when the singular crosses the universal [Hegelian?], when the categorical engages the idiomatic
BL.linkedContent: literature: when the singular crosses the universal [Hegelian?], when the categorical engages the idiomatic

BL.content: generic distinction of form/content in literature: form is signifying expression, phenomena of language or rhetoric [don’t confuse form w/ framing]
BL.linkedContent: generic distinction of form/content in literature: form is signifying expression, phenomena of language or rhetoric [don’t confuse form w/ framing]

BL.content: that which makes literature possible is outside literature
BL.linkedContent: that which makes literature possible is outside literature

BL.content: different periods of history of positive law give substance to literature, value of signatures [“authors”]
BL.linkedContent: different periods of history of positive law give substance to literature, value of signatures [“authors”]

BL.content: all watchmen (critics, academics, literary theorists, writers, and philosophers), who guard positive laws, value of signatures, & identity of corpora, receive same answer in their appeal to the law: differance > plus de loi et plus de littérature
BL.linkedContent: all watchmen (critics, academics, literary theorists, writers, and philosophers), who guard positive laws, value of signatures, & identity of corpora, receive same answer in their appeal to the law: differance > plus de loi et plus de littérature

BL.content: overflowing of literature, literariness does not belong to literature
BL.linkedContent: overflowing of literature, literariness does not belong to literature

BL.content: work, opus, does not belong to field, transforms it
BL.linkedContent: work, opus, does not belong to field, transforms it

BL.content: literature makes law, power of performativity—sidestep existing laws which condition its emergence (jouer la loi [play, deceive the law])
BL.linkedContent: literature makes law, power of performativity—sidestep existing laws which condition its emergence (jouer la loi [play, deceive the law])

SICL.content: literature is not Greek-poetry: relation to a specific juridico-politico guarantee
SICL.linkedContent: literature is not Greek-poetry: relation to a specific juridico-politico guarantee

HASD.content: to doubt divine promise, transgress the injunction [of hyperessential, negative theological God], would be to see an opening (closing in on itself) of literariness, lawless law of fiction
HASD.linkedContent: to doubt divine promise, transgress the injunction [of hyperessential, negative theological God], would be to see an opening (closing in on itself) of literariness, lawless law of fiction

MPM.content: de Man: “deconstruction of metaphysics” is impossible because in being rhetorical (btwn trope & persuasion) it is literary (doesn’t resolve relation btwn literature & philosophy)
MPM.linkedContent: de Man: “deconstruction of metaphysics” is impossible because in being rhetorical (btwn trope & persuasion) it is literary (doesn’t resolve relation btwn literature & philosophy)

EM.content: Heidegger: written form exerts wholesome pressure, present world crisis needs less philosophy, more thinking, less literature, we must liberate Dichtung from literature
EM.linkedContent: Heidegger: written form exerts wholesome pressure, present world crisis needs less philosophy, more thinking, less literature, we must liberate Dichtung from literature

PP.content: the 3 eras of “Platonism” (Plato, Saussure, and Rousseau), which put writing out of question while borrowing from it all its demonstrative/theoretical resources, must come to terms w/: 1) generalized sort of writing 2) a “contradiction”: written proposal of logocentrism 3) construction of “literary” work
PP.linkedContent: the 3 eras of “Platonism” (Plato, Saussure, and Rousseau), which put writing out of question while borrowing from it all its demonstrative/theoretical resources, must come to terms w/: 1) generalized sort of writing 2) a “contradiction”: written proposal of logocentrism 3) construction of “literary” work

SH.content: philosophy finds itself in vicinity of poetic, of literature, the blurred border (no place, utopia) btwn empirical (contingency of the outer) and necessary (necessity of inner) > indecision of this limit most provokes thought [Derrida attacks the idea that philosophy loses itself there]
SH.linkedContent: philosophy finds itself in vicinity of poetic, of literature, the blurred border (no place, utopia) btwn empirical (contingency of the outer) and necessary (necessity of inner) > indecision of this limit most provokes thought [Derrida attacks the idea that philosophy loses itself there]

SH.content: poetry, literature, art, experience of the mask, an intense familiarity w/ ineluctable originarity of specter = ineluctable loss of origin > spectral errancy of words not an accident
SH.linkedContent: poetry, literature, art, experience of the mask, an intense familiarity w/ ineluctable originarity of specter = ineluctable loss of origin > spectral errancy of words not an accident

FWT.content: literature transforms/displaces status of public space, affects w/ irreducible novelty > transforms public space w/in, amidst, like “new technologies” of communication/reproduction
FWT.linkedContent: literature transforms/displaces status of public space, affects w/ irreducible novelty > transforms public space w/in, amidst, like “new technologies” of communication/reproduction

FWT.content: literature is the [an-]institution of absolute candor & freedom, under no positive law, mutation in concept of responsibility
FWT.linkedContent: literature is the [an-]institution of absolute candor & freedom, under no positive law, mutation in concept of responsibility

FWT.content: by inventing/violating modality of as if, revealing its infinity, literature endlessly opens up to historicity of political, w/ certain concept of democracy-to-come ——as if an increased responsibility in absolute freedom of literature, a certain mode of address
FWT.linkedContent: by inventing/violating modality of as if, revealing its infinity, literature endlessly opens up to historicity of political, w/ certain concept of democracy-to-come ——as if an increased responsibility in absolute freedom of literature, a certain mode of address

FWT.content: beyond good and evil: only country of literature
FWT.linkedContent: beyond good and evil: only country of literature

FWT.content: we should only censor when something is not literature [?]
FWT.linkedContent: we should only censor when something is not literature [?]

FWT.content: common possibilities of literature & democracy: 1) historicity (literature has acts, birthplaces, legacies; democracy defines itself by promising itself, by and in its historicity, its future-to-come) 2) power, credit of fiction [Montaigne/Pascal understood connection btwn right & fiction]
FWT.linkedContent: common possibilities of literature & democracy: 1) historicity (literature has acts, birthplaces, legacies; democracy defines itself by promising itself, by and in its historicity, its future-to-come) 2) power, credit of fiction [Montaigne/Pascal understood connection btwn right & fiction]

FWT.content: literature a recent invention, threatened by death, repeats its birth beginning from its end, from a finitude that is its resource & essential specter
FWT.linkedContent: literature a recent invention, threatened by death, repeats its birth beginning from its end, from a finitude that is its resource & essential specter

POOF.content: via Deguy, is literature [linked to democracy, which has no unconditional virtue] the very thing which remains intolerable to the geopolitical process of a becoming-worldwide (mondialité)? > absolute theologization qua absolute politicization
POOF.linkedContent: via Deguy, is literature [linked to democracy, which has no unconditional virtue] the very thing which remains intolerable to the geopolitical process of a becoming-worldwide (mondialité)? > absolute theologization qua absolute politicization

DS.content: double session finds its corner (coin) BTWN (ENTRE) literature & truth (that by which question “what is?” wants answering): figure of folding back, angle ensured by fold
DS.linkedContent: double session finds its corner (coin) BTWN (ENTRE) literature & truth (that by which question “what is?” wants answering): figure of folding back, angle ensured by fold

DS.content: literature voids itself in its limitlessness
DS.linkedContent: literature voids itself in its limitlessness

DS.content: Mallarmé: beyond is literature’s [?] agent, dismantle literary mechanism to display nothing
DS.linkedContent: Mallarmé: beyond is literature’s [?] agent, dismantle literary mechanism to display nothing

DS.content: literary criticism, linked to possibility of decidability, to krinein, goes into crisis > Cris de vers
DS.linkedContent: literary criticism, linked to possibility of decidability, to krinein, goes into crisis > Cris de vers

DS.content: “literary criticism” —ontological interpretation of mimesis? krinein proceeds precisely from out of that which is being threatened by the re-tempering (retrempe) of literature
DS.linkedContent: “literary criticism” —ontological interpretation of mimesis? krinein proceeds precisely from out of that which is being threatened by the re-tempering (retrempe) of literature

DS.content: [quoting Mallarmé] rhythm, literary game par excellence: mimic suspense/laughter—rhythmic cadence, or case, all the falls, the silent fall of pen
DS.linkedContent: [quoting Mallarmé] rhythm, literary game par excellence: mimic suspense/laughter—rhythmic cadence, or case, all the falls, the silent fall of pen

DS.content: the crisis of literature takes place when nothing takes place (a lieu) but the place > instance where no one is there to know
DS.linkedContent: the crisis of literature takes place when nothing takes place (a lieu) but the place > instance where no one is there to know

POS.content: Heidegger’s phonologism, privileging of poem over literature
POS.linkedContent: Heidegger’s phonologism, privileging of poem over literature

POS.content: Derrida’s texts belong neither to “philosophical” nor “literary” register, communicate w/ other texts that can be called “philosophical” or “literary” acc. a kind of paleonomy
POS.linkedContent: Derrida’s texts belong neither to “philosophical” nor “literary” register, communicate w/ other texts that can be called “philosophical” or “literary” acc. a kind of paleonomy

ROP.content: Bartleby as figure of death, as secret of literature, makes narrator (man of law) talk
ROP.linkedContent: Bartleby as figure of death, as secret of literature, makes narrator (man of law) talk

FS.content: [metaphor of structuralism]: a city no longer inhabited, reduced to its skeleton, haunted by meaning & culture > cette hantise is the mode (absent/present) of thing itself in pure language (housed in pure literature)
FS.linkedContent: [metaphor of structuralism]: a city no longer inhabited, reduced to its skeleton, haunted by meaning & culture > cette hantise is the mode (absent/present) of thing itself in pure language (housed in pure literature)

O.content: adventurous excess of writing not improv., throw of dice doesn’t contradict rigorous necessity of its “formal assemblage”: unity of chance & rule, program and its leftovers or extra (son reste ou de son surplus) [literature or book: atheistic face of this play, conflagration achieved, final clause located sur la tranche du livre fermé]
O.linkedContent: adventurous excess of writing not improv., throw of dice doesn’t contradict rigorous necessity of its “formal assemblage”: unity of chance & rule, program and its leftovers or extra (son reste ou de son surplus) [literature or book: atheistic face of this play, conflagration achieved, final clause located sur la tranche du livre fermé]

O.content: literature is beyond of everything: author would have to disappear along w/ literature
O.linkedContent: literature is beyond of everything: author would have to disappear along w/ literature

O.content: literature is the exception in the whole and the exception to everything (l’exception de tout) (subtraction w/out lack), part (pièce) which exists by itself [solitude], marks le tout autre
O.linkedContent: literature is the exception in the whole and the exception to everything (l’exception de tout) (subtraction w/out lack), part (pièce) which exists by itself [solitude], marks le tout autre

O.content: is pleasure literary in essence? if Vorlust, foreplay, prime (bonus) of seduction, formal moment of literature, ne se comble qu’à la fin du plaisir, then jouissance would be instance of seduction, prime supplémentaire de rien d’autre: pleasure a formal, threshold phenomena, nul et sans fins, a repression lifted & maintained > graphics of hymen questions all couples, all oppositions (especially those of Freud)
O.linkedContent: is pleasure literary in essence? if Vorlust, foreplay, prime (bonus) of seduction, formal moment of literature, ne se comble qu’à la fin du plaisir, then jouissance would be instance of seduction, prime supplémentaire de rien d’autre: pleasure a formal, threshold phenomena, nul et sans fins, a repression lifted & maintained > graphics of hymen questions all couples, all oppositions (especially those of Freud)

DPi.content: literature (past 3/4 centuries) coincides w/ abolitionist thought > risky hypothesis
DPi.linkedContent: literature (past 3/4 centuries) coincides w/ abolitionist thought > risky hypothesis

DPi.content: time of bandages: when body not found—when Jesus is not dead but not yet elevated, resuscitated > the lodging made ready for literature: ascension w/out ascension, elevation w/out elevation, immanence w/out immanence, imminent yet unaccomplished resurrection
DPi.linkedContent: time of bandages: when body not found—when Jesus is not dead but not yet elevated, resuscitated > the lodging made ready for literature: ascension w/out ascension, elevation w/out elevation, immanence w/out immanence, imminent yet unaccomplished resurrection

DPi.content: moment before noli me tangere [p. 35n unique moment, since Jesus is generally a touching Jesus], moment where mourning can’t set to work, there’s no corpse > when Mary and Antigone weep over absence of burial
DPi.linkedContent: moment before noli me tangere [p. 35n unique moment, since Jesus is generally a touching Jesus], moment where mourning can’t set to work, there’s no corpse > when Mary and Antigone weep over absence of burial

DPi.content: instant of bandages, Christ’s being-there w/out being-there: this Dasein that is not a Da-sein, this Fort/Da-sein of Christ who’s dead but not dead, mort vivant
DPi.linkedContent: instant of bandages, Christ’s being-there w/out being-there: this Dasein that is not a Da-sein, this Fort/Da-sein of Christ who’s dead but not dead, mort vivant

DPi.content: Hugo (conscious of historical responsibility of writer/literature): writers of 18th century destroyed torture; writers of 19th century will destroy DP; p. 104 destroy it w/ divine hammer of pen > profoundly Christian stance, btwn profound flourish & faith, for intérieur
DPi.linkedContent: Hugo (conscious of historical responsibility of writer/literature): writers of 18th century destroyed torture; writers of 19th century will destroy DP; p. 104 destroy it w/ divine hammer of pen > profoundly Christian stance, btwn profound flourish & faith, for intérieur

DPi.content: for Hugo, responsibility, sacred right of writer—cosmopolitical
writer’s right a right that gives the right to go beyond rights, “civil disobedience”; for Hugo, DP too human, abolition is divine law
DPi.linkedContent: writer’s right a right that gives the right to go beyond rights, “civil disobedience”; for Hugo, DP too human, abolition is divine law

DPi.content: [vis-à-vis Hugo] border line of right to literature divides a good & bad Christianity
DPi.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Hugo] border line of right to literature divides a good & bad Christianity

DPi.content: Blanchot: literature is Terror in that its being is where “life bears death and maintains itself in death itself” [quotation from Hegel]
DPi.linkedContent: Blanchot: literature is Terror in that its being is where “life bears death and maintains itself in death itself” [quotation from Hegel]

DPi.content: for Blanchot, literature is revolutionary on the side of death; for Hugo, on the side of life
DPi.linkedContent: for Blanchot, literature is revolutionary on the side of death; for Hugo, on the side of life

DPi.content: Blanchot: “any writer who, by the very fact of writing, is not induced to think: I am the revolution, only freedom makes me write, is not really writing”
DPi.linkedContent: Blanchot: “any writer who, by the very fact of writing, is not induced to think: I am the revolution, only freedom makes me write, is not really writing”

DPi.content: Blanchot’s “literature as right to death” is not against DP, literature as last act, last judgment, theater of cruelty, both eschatological & apocalyptic
DPi.linkedContent: Blanchot’s “literature as right to death” is not against DP, literature as last act, last judgment, theater of cruelty, both eschatological & apocalyptic

DPi.content: Blanchot’s right to death: right to give it, giving it to oneself (en se la donnant), inflicting DP; right to accede to death (not natural) by exceeding natural life > both the right that gives birth to literature and the law that gives birth to the law itself: literature thinks this right of/to right
DPi.linkedContent: Blanchot’s right to death: right to give it, giving it to oneself (en se la donnant), inflicting DP; right to accede to death (not natural) by exceeding natural life > both the right that gives birth to literature and the law that gives birth to the law itself: literature thinks this right of/to right

DPi.content: Derrida believes in correctness of interpreting Blanchot’s “Literature and the Right to Death” as a terrorist, terrorizing thinking of literature > but: 1) literary language is contradictory 2) death is a principle of salvation/resurrection 3) dying becomes an impossibility
DPi.linkedContent: Derrida believes in correctness of interpreting Blanchot’s “Literature and the Right to Death” as a terrorist, terrorizing thinking of literature > but: 1) literary language is contradictory 2) death is a principle of salvation/resurrection 3) dying becomes an impossibility

DPi.content: literature “expresses w/out expressing,” “this death w/out death” defines horizon w/out horizon of responsibility w/out responsibility of writer
DPi.linkedContent: literature “expresses w/out expressing,” “this death w/out death” defines horizon w/out horizon of responsibility w/out responsibility of writer

DPi.content: Blanchot: literature divided btwn 2 slopes, interminable “resifting (ressassement) of words”
DPi.linkedContent: Blanchot: literature divided btwn 2 slopes, interminable “resifting (ressassement) of words”

Gii.content: logo-phonocentrism in Heidegger: writing declines thought, escapes draft when it enters literature [Derrida briefly directs us to Heidegger’s meditation on chreōn, Brauch, necessity, logos]
Gii.linkedContent: logo-phonocentrism in Heidegger: writing declines thought, escapes draft when it enters literature [Derrida briefly directs us to Heidegger’s meditation on chreōn, Brauch, necessity, logos]

TR.content: possible fiction, mēkhanē of a dramaturgy, supplement of fiction, inscribe in the archive of a new, quasi-literary genre (confessions) > palimpsestuous [insect/incest], encrypted lineage
TR.linkedContent: possible fiction, mēkhanē of a dramaturgy, supplement of fiction, inscribe in the archive of a new, quasi-literary genre (confessions) > palimpsestuous [insect/incest], encrypted lineage

TR.content: confession (a veracity of testimony) never makes concessions to lies of literature
TR.linkedContent: confession (a veracity of testimony) never makes concessions to lies of literature

EJQB.content: books are always books of life, or of afterlife > written questions addressed to literature are forgotten, drained, by literature (mortifications, ruses of life, life negating itself in literature to survive): writing would die of pure vigilance to question (and also simple erasure of question)
EJQB.linkedContent: books are always books of life, or of afterlife > written questions addressed to literature are forgotten, drained, by literature (mortifications, ruses of life, life negating itself in literature to survive): writing would die of pure vigilance to question (and also simple erasure of question)

EJQB.content: absolute interrogation (of God) will never belong to the book
EJQB.linkedContent: absolute interrogation (of God) will never belong to the book

EJQB.content: to write: to confuse ontology & grammar; grammar: in which are inscribed all dislocations of dead syntax, all aggressions perpetrated by speech against language, every questioning of the letter
EJQB.linkedContent: to write: to confuse ontology & grammar; grammar: in which are inscribed all dislocations of dead syntax, all aggressions perpetrated by speech against language, every questioning of the letter

EJQB.content: all these tortures are forgotten in literature, as mortifications, as ruses of life
EJQB.linkedContent: all these tortures are forgotten in literature, as mortifications, as ruses of life

EJQB.content: life negates itself in literature only so it may survive better—be better
EJQB.linkedContent: life negates itself in literature only so it may survive better—be better

EJQB.content: pure literature is nonliterature or death
literature, perhaps: dreamlike displacement of the question
EJQB.linkedContent: literature, perhaps: dreamlike displacement of the question

PJP.content: anacoluthon, generalized, causes all “subjects” to tremble (disturbance of identification), passes border btwn fiction/reality, btwn literature/testimony > even if erases border still a highly significant structural field: the duel of friendship, the question of “us”
PJP.linkedContent: anacoluthon, generalized, causes all “subjects” to tremble (disturbance of identification), passes border btwn fiction/reality, btwn literature/testimony > even if erases border still a highly significant structural field: the duel of friendship, the question of “us”

PJP.content: narrative of a disappearance: signature gets erased moment it enters literature [like question in EJQB]
PJP.linkedContent: narrative of a disappearance: signature gets erased moment it enters literature [like question in EJQB]

D.content: no one can enter Soller’s Numbers who thinks literature/thought ought to exorcise the machine (that the 2 have nothing to do w/ each other)
D.linkedContent: no one can enter Soller’s Numbers who thinks literature/thought ought to exorcise the machine (that the 2 have nothing to do w/ each other)

LI.content: did Derrida make seriousness of philosophical discourse skid towards literary play [parasitizing Descartes’ title in SEC]? unless seriousness were already the para-site of such play
LI.linkedContent: did Derrida make seriousness of philosophical discourse skid towards literary play [parasitizing Descartes’ title in SEC]? unless seriousness were already the para-site of such play

LI.content: laws, in their normality, entail something fictional, depend on some structural power that allows fictions, lies, to take place: thus importance of studying literature to understand law
LI.linkedContent: laws, in their normality, entail something fictional, depend on some structural power that allows fictions, lies, to take place: thus importance of studying literature to understand law

LG.content: all texts left open, eternally remarkable—possibility of becoming literature
LG.linkedContent: all texts left open, eternally remarkable—possibility of becoming literature

LG.content: l’épreuve of a récit brought to light the madness of genre—spinning (faire tourner) Peterson’s genre-disc, comme un soleil fou > dividing borders btwn literature and its others
LG.linkedContent: l’épreuve of a récit brought to light the madness of genre—spinning (faire tourner) Peterson’s genre-disc, comme un soleil fou > dividing borders btwn literature and its others

LG.content: “this is the whole of it,” only what “I” see, kneeling [à genoux] at edge of literature, “le loi en somme, ce que ‘je’ voit et que ‘je’ dit que je vois en un récit où je/nous somme”
LG.linkedContent: “this is the whole of it,” only what “I” see, kneeling [à genoux] at edge of literature, “le loi en somme, ce que ‘je’ voit et que ‘je’ dit que je vois en un récit où je/nous somme”

BSi.content: acc. Deleuze, “best” literature, not pseudo-literature, not philosophy, lets itself be haunted by bêtise
BSi.linkedContent: acc. Deleuze, “best” literature, not pseudo-literature, not philosophy, lets itself be haunted by bêtise

IF.content: [vis-à-vis Flaubert] as paradoxical as it sounds, Hegel frees passage for literature or writing called Art > having reached its end, one can discredit philosophy by treating it as art
IF.linkedContent: [vis-à-vis Flaubert] as paradoxical as it sounds, Hegel frees passage for literature or writing called Art > having reached its end, one can discredit philosophy by treating it as art

UWC.content: Derrida links new concept of humanities [a deconstructive one] w/ democratic institution called literature, to a certain simulacrum, a certain “as if”
UWC.linkedContent: Derrida links new concept of humanities [a deconstructive one] w/ democratic institution called literature, to a certain simulacrum, a certain “as if”

UWC.content: “literature,” its link to performative force of “as if,” to the right to say everything (or not to say everything), which founds both democracy & unconditional sovereignty claimed by Humanities
UWC.linkedContent: “literature,” its link to performative force of “as if,” to the right to say everything (or not to say everything), which founds both democracy & unconditional sovereignty claimed by Humanities

CIR.content: desire for literature is circumcision, text read does not suffice, has to be eaten, sucked
CIR.linkedContent: desire for literature is circumcision, text read does not suffice, has to be eaten, sucked

CIR.content: nervous, worried, hunted, literature (beast playing dead, melding w/ foliage), delivering to world impregnable inedible simulacrum, the theory of the parasite virus, terrorizing others w/ instability he carries everywhere, one book open in the other
CIR.linkedContent: nervous, worried, hunted, literature (beast playing dead, melding w/ foliage), delivering to world impregnable inedible simulacrum, the theory of the parasite virus, terrorizing others w/ instability he carries everywhere, one book open in the other

EU.content: Derrida’s 1st thesis title: The Ideality of the Literary Object > Derrida tells Hyppolite: if I saw where I was going, I wouldn’t take another step
EU.linkedContent: Derrida’s 1st thesis title: The Ideality of the Literary Object > Derrida tells Hyppolite: if I saw where I was going, I wouldn’t take another step

SPEC.content: Beyond… is a-thetic, no (final) judgment, indefinite suspension re: life death > death drive appears/disappears while telling stories, making scenes: myths, fables (literary)
SPEC.linkedContent: Beyond… is a-thetic, no (final) judgment, indefinite suspension re: life death > death drive appears/disappears while telling stories, making scenes: myths, fables (literary)

SPEC.content: “literary fiction” in fort:da, fait-oeuvre in abyss of these repetitions, fairies, demons, unheimlich repetitions, what is most gripping (saisissant) and ungraspable (insaisissable) about Beyond…, for Freud too, who believed he could affix the seal of the Freuds to it [Beyond…] while hearing voices
SPEC.linkedContent: “literary fiction” in fort:da, fait-oeuvre in abyss of these repetitions, fairies, demons, unheimlich repetitions, what is most gripping (saisissant) and ungraspable (insaisissable) about Beyond…, for Freud too, who believed he could affix the seal of the Freuds to it [Beyond…] while hearing voices

SPEC.content: [re: Freud’s Beyond…] speculating, “author” already no longer there, no longer responsible, leaves document in your hands > “literary”: make of it what you will, it’s up to you—you’re more than ever on board
SPEC.linkedContent: [re: Freud’s Beyond…] speculating, “author” already no longer there, no longer responsible, leaves document in your hands > “literary”: make of it what you will, it’s up to you—you’re more than ever on board

SPEC.content: no theses in science or literature (athetic), every thesis is philosophical
SPEC.linkedContent: no theses in science or literature (athetic), every thesis is philosophical

FV.content: literature that puts truth on stage, can it be read by psychoanalysis? abyssal structure, this space overflowed by powers of simulacrum
FV.linkedContent: literature that puts truth on stage, can it be read by psychoanalysis? abyssal structure, this space overflowed by powers of simulacrum

FV.content: in France, “literary criticism” marked by psychoanalysis has not asked question of the text
FV.linkedContent: in France, “literary criticism” marked by psychoanalysis has not asked question of the text

FV.content: even Freud [thus not Lacan] indicates, in Das Unheimliche, literary fiction’s resistance to general law of psychoanalytic knowledge
FV.linkedContent: even Freud [thus not Lacan] indicates, in Das Unheimliche, literary fiction’s resistance to general law of psychoanalytic knowledge

FV.content: signer dispossessed [re: The Purloined…], signature in quotations: ce reste est encore de la littérature
FV.linkedContent: signer dispossessed [re: The Purloined…], signature in quotations: ce reste est encore de la littérature
